Hi J.B.,

As Agitar's co-founde=
r and CTO, I always hesitate to jump into product
discussions in this forum=
; but in this case it might be useful to
clarify some things.  Especially s=
ince the discussion seems to be
quite civilized so far :-).

>so my opinion=
 is largely 
>theoretical in nature at present.

Thank you for recognizing =
that, but I can see how (based on the brief
description of our pricing mode=
l) you would reach your conclusions -
so we have to fix that and be clearer=
.

In practice, the number of classes on which the license is based is
meas=
ured more in orders or magnitudes than an very precise class
count.  Many o=
f our licenses are actually enterprise-wide and for an
unlimited number of =
users or classes.  In all cases, there is ample
head-room for adding new cl=
asses and refactoring big-old-nasty
classes.  As a matter of fact, one of t=
he top uses for our JUnit
generation is to help create a safety net for wor=
king with legacy
code; and class/method refactoring is one of the things th=
at we
recommend.  You can see me giving a demo of exactly that type of
refa=
ctoring (at the method level) at:

http://www.agitar.com/solutions/products=
/agitarone_demos.html

(It's the first of the four mini-demos on that page =
... No making fun
of my accent please, and NO we did not hire Borat to do t=
he voice over
:-)).

Every pricing scheme has advantages and disadvantages.=
  Most of us
want to move away from per-seat licensing. I believe that a
se=
rver-based solution with an unlimited number of classes (or with a
very gen=
erous over-allotment for growth and refactoring) is a step in
the right dir=
ection, but we are open to exploring other suggestions
(like the one you al=
ready made).

Thanks,

Alberto
